evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, showing consistent patterns without contradictory information.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident, including timing and crew interaction patterns.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal is documented and accessible within the operational records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations based on available evidence.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members reflect communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation
No corroborated hardware faults occurred
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical failure or environmental/marking deficiencies were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate a lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew interactions and possible procedural deviations

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: No mechanical fault was reported or detected in the evidence
The pushback incident was primarily influenced by human factors and communication
Environmental factors (markings, TRP) were not the primary cause
defeaters: If direct evidence of mechanical or control system faults on the aircraft during the pushback were found
If fault codes or repeated malfunctions were verified indicating mechanical failure
If hardware bench checks confirmed control system malfunction

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the aircraft was pushed past the TRP and hit the blast fence despite no reported mechanical faults; the tug instructor and others indicate procedural and communication issues rather than mechanical failure, favoring procedural deviation and communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on operator reports and procedural observations

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident, including timing and crew interaction patterns.

assumptions: Crew interaction patterns and timing described reflect communication/coordination breakdown
No contradictory evidence from other sources outside the provided history
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation as the primary cause rather than communication issues
If mechanical faults were identified that explained the event without coordination breakdown
If environmental or marking deficiencies were the main cause of the incident

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If direct evidence of missing, inadequate, or unclear TRP markings on the aircraft or ground at the time were found
If witnesses reported that the TRP was not visible or identifiable during the inspection
If physical inspection or documentation showed environmental or marking deficiencies

Instead, evidence (H8, H10, H12, H13) points to procedural and communication issues, such as insufficient visual signals and lack of warnings, favoring procedural deviation and communication breakdown over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct evidence about marking presence or condition; reliance on indirect testimony about procedures and communication

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal is documented and accessible within the operational records.

assumptions: The history evidence items represent operational records or are derived from them
The documented history is accessible within operational records as claimed
defeaters: If operational records were not accessible or did not document the deviation explicitly
If evidence showed mechanical failure or environmental factors as primary causes
If communication breakdown evidence was stronger and documented

Crew qualifications and training described reflect standard operational context
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or tug equipment failure causing the incident
If communication signals or warnings were clearly given and ignored
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 is the key feature referenced in the claim.
The adequacy and visibility of markings are critical to fit the key features and criteria.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were absent or incorrect for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, or if the marking was clearly visible and adequate but the incident was due to procedural or communication failures, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP marking and clearance for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, supporting the claim that the environmental marking corresponds to key features. However, H8 and H13 indicate challenges in visibility and signaling, suggesting the marking was present but possibly insufficiently clear or visible, which supports the claim that the deficiency fits the key features criteria.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking deficiency alone caused the incident or if procedural and communication factors were more significant

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

defeaters: If additional evidence showed that the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members under all conditions
If procedural communication and signaling methods were proven fully effective and consistently used

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and adequacy of the TRP marking; H8 and H13 indicate limitations in visual signaling and marking size that could undermine robustness against defeaters during pushback, supporting the claim that identification must be robust.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of visual signals and marking visibility

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, showing consistent patterns without contradictory information.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination patterns described are complete and accurately reflect the event.
No undisclosed mechanical faults or procedural deviations influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit warnings or alerts from wingman or headset operator that were ignored, or hardware faults occurred, this would challenge the resistance claim.
If procedural deviations were clearly documented as primary cause, resistance to defeaters would weaken.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8, H10, H12) shows consistent communication and coordination patterns among crew with no contradictory information, supporting resistance to defeaters. Discriminators favor communication breakdown over procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in interpreting crew assumptions and unspoken expectations; no direct contradictory evidence but limited explicit communication details.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: No mechanical or control system faults were reported or observed in the evidence provided.
The incident was primarily influenced by human factors and communication breakdown.
defeaters: If direct evidence of hardware faults or control malfunctions were found in the aircraft systems or tug equipment during the incident.
If corroborated fault codes or repeat malfunctions were documented indicating mechanical failure.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8, H10, H12) indicates no hardware faults or mechanical malfunction were observed; rather, communication and coordination issues among personnel led to the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast fence, contradicting the claim of mechanical/control failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; reliance on personnel communication and procedural observations

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t3_prefinal withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations based on available evidence.

assumptions: The visual signals described by the tug instructor are the standard method for stopping the tug.
No mechanical failure or environmental deficiency contributed to the pushback beyond the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear communication signals were given and ignored, or if environmental or mechanical factors forced the pushback beyond the TRP, this would challenge the procedural deviation conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the tug instructor continued past the TRP without stopping despite signals and expectations, indicating procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown, supporting the claim that procedural deviation withstands counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists in the adequacy of communication signals and situational awareness among crew, but no evidence indicates alternative causes.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality records of radios, intercoms, and other communication equipment during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical and incident reports to determine if any crew member was incapacitated or distracted

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were absent or unreachable during the operation, or communication was impossible, this would change the assessment.

outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly addresses crew presence and reachability.

node.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts

assumptions: Effective communication implies ability to respond
No mention of incapacitation or inability to respond in evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were incapacitated or unable to respond to communication attempts
If communication devices failed or were unavailable

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H10, and H12 indicate crew members were communicative and responsive, with no incapacitation or inability to respond to communication attempts, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statements about incapacitation; inference based on communication and behavior descriptions

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and operational logs for equipment readiness and downtime records during the pushback period

children_spec.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform pushback according to procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew rosters, training records, and duty schedules to confirm presence of qualified staff during pushback

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and accessibility of pushback procedure manuals or digital resources at the operational site

node.statement: Availability of clear and accessible procedural documentation for pushback

assumptions: Training on TRP implies existence and availability of procedural documentation.
Statements about knowledge of TRP from training reflect accessible procedural documentation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that procedural documentation was unclear, inaccessible, or not provided to the crew, or if environmental factors like marker visibility were inadequate, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
The wingman ... commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, H9, H11, and H13 directly indicate that procedural documentation and training regarding the TRP existed and was accessible, supporting availability of clear procedural documentation for pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states the procedural documentation's physical accessibility or clarity beyond training knowledge; some ambiguity remains about documentation format and availability.

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location for the presence of all required environmental markings according to regulatory and company standards

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

defeaters: If evidence showed that all crew members actively used communication devices effectively and warnings were given and acknowledged.
If there were technical failures or access issues with communication devices.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 confirms communication devices were operational; however, H8, H11, and H12 indicate lack of effective communication or warnings among crew members, contradicting the claim that communication devices and channels were accessible and effectively used by all crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication devices were accessible but not effectively used versus not accessible at all

node.statement: Environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions

assumptions: Assuming that the description of TRP location and size implies markings were visible and legible as no contrary evidence is provided.
defeaters: If evidence showed that TRP markings were obscured, damaged, or illegible under operational conditions, this would support environmental marking deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking and its visibility; no direct indication that markings were not visible or legible under operational conditions, favoring procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform pushback according to procedure

assumptions: The presence of trained personnel implies availability to perform pushback according to procedure.
The continuation past the TRP despite signals indicates procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor or trainee lacked training or awareness of the TRP or procedure, or if communication failures were documented explicitly, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H4, H8, H10, H12) shows trained personnel were present and involved in the pushback procedure, but the pushback continued past the TRP causing collision, indicating procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence of communication failure or environmental/technical issues; ambiguity remains about exact cause of deviation.

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: The availability of pushback equipment is confirmed by presence and operation of tug and crew (H1, H2)
No mechanical faults were reported or observed during the incident
Environmental markings (TRP) were adequate and visible as per H7 and H13
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults with the tug or control systems (contradicting H4, H8)
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible (contradicting H7, H13)
If communication breakdown was documented between crew members leading to the incident

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H4, H8, H9, H10, H12) shows the pushback equipment was available and operated by qualified personnel, but procedural deviation occurred as the tug continued past the TRP and hit the blast barrier. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environmental marking deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiency; assumptions rely on witness statements and training records.

node.statement: Required environmental markings are present at the location

assumptions: Presence of TRP markings as described in H7 and H13 implies required environmental markings are present.
No evidence indicates markings were missing or not visible.
defeaters: If evidence showed missing or obscured TRP markings or physical environmental deficiencies at the location.
If crew or operators reported inability to see or identify the TRP markings.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 confirm the presence of required environmental markings (TRP), while H8 and H12 show communication failures and lack of alerts, favoring communication breakdown over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: small size of TRP and subjective perception of marking adequacy

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

node.statement: All crew members were present and available during the critical phases of flight

assumptions: Presence of crew members implies availability unless evidence indicates otherwise.
Communication via interphone and visual signals are considered forms of availability.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit warnings or interventions by crew members during the critical phase, or if crew were physically absent or unavailable, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows crew communication and presence, but H8, H10, and H12 indicate lack of effective warnings and assumptions leading to the pushback continuing past the TRP, contradicting the claim that all crew were present and available during critical phases.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication effectiveness and availability despite physical presence

node.statement: Environmental conditions do not obscure or degrade marking visibility

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was obscured by environmental conditions or markings were degraded, this would support the claim.

quotes.exact_quote: He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H13 indicates the TRP marking was small but does not state it was obscured or degraded, suggesting environmental conditions did not obscure or degrade marking visibility, thus contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited direct evidence on marking visibility and environmental conditions
